ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We looked at theories surrounding photography and family photography and learned different ways to see and analyze family photography and its meanings.
I learned how to think about family photographs and photography in a critical and overarching way in concerns to its connection to society.
How to analyze family photography from a theoretical perspective, and how to think through our emotional responses to photography. How to "close read" a photograph.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learning how to look at family photography can be very insightful and help you gain deeper perspective on how to look at your own family photographs.

Strength - the final assignment!
Weakness - the readings can be a little difficult difficult parse through at first, but it gets easier as the course progresses!

Strengths: All of the readings were fascinating (especially if you like reading theory) and our discussions generally were as well. I especially liked our early-in-the-semester practice of bringing in photographs (from our own families or elsewhere) that we felt resonated with the readings and presenting them to the class. There was often an emotional element to these presentations that I found captivating.

Weaknesses: Sometimes I felt that our discussions were a bit tangential and directionless, which made it occasionally hard to stay engaged, especially over Zoom.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The online seminars worked well and the virtual field trip to Beinecke was also very fun.
I think the format was good!

Sometimes Professor Wexler had a bit of trouble figuring out where we could get online versions of the readings that she assigned, which could be frustrating. Overall, though, I feel that our discussions succeeded in a virtual format and we were still able to closely analyze photographs together, which of course was the purpose of the class!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are interested in photography or learning perspective on examining photography, and even your own family photography, I recommend taking the class. You can end up learning a lot about other photographs, as well as your own family.
Absolutely! It is a stimulating class with an extremely low workload.

Yes, as long as you like the idea of learning more about your own responses to family photography from an intellectual perspective! It would also probably be preferable for you to enjoy reading theorybecause this isn't my favorite kind of reading, I sometimes struggled to get through the homework, but I still feel that I enjoyed and learned a lot from the course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: One virtual field trip to the Beinecke and different guests that came and talked to the class.
A few guest speakers who gave short lectures and answered questions!
